div.head: A Century and Beyond: The History of Purdue University. By Robert W. Topping. (West Lafayette, Ind.: Purdue University Press, 1988. Pp. xv, 418. Illustrations, appendix, bibliography, index. $27.50.)
div.p: Visitors to Purdue University see a workaday campus embracing massive, functional-looking buildings; not a glamourous campus, but one that conveys a sense of ordered purposefulness. This visual impression is an outward manifestation of the university's essence. For over one hundred years a succession of strong, businesslike presidents molded Purdue into one of the nation's foremost engineering and scientific institutions. This book is the story of these presidential leaders, who they were and what they accomplished. It is, therefore, not so much a comprehensive history of the entire university effort as it is a series of mini-biographies of presidential leaders and their chief administrative assistants.

Although histories by their very nature deal with beginnings, Topping gives unusual attention to the historical forces that led to the creation of Indiana's land-grant college. Long sections dealing with pioneer society and with Justin Morrill's struggle to get his land-grant college act passed by Congress seem excessive; but once John Purdue, prosperous Hoosier farmer and entrepreneur, focuses Indiana's stumbling efforts to erect an A&M school by giving $150,000 to the cause, things start moving. Despite John Purdue's effort to direct the enterprise, the college was shaped by its presidents. From an early time they moved it toward a concentration on engineering, thus provoking agriculturalists who felt their interests were being slighted. In due time Purdue University would be recognized for its work in the agricultural sciences, but that part of its program was always overshadowed by its striking accomplishments in engineering and related disciplines. Aggressive presidents and administrators, many of them engineers by training, seized every new opportunity from aeronautics to computers to keep Purdue at the forefront of engineering science.

The dominance of engineering and the "hard" sciences is such that readers find no reference to the humanities until they have digested some three hundred pages of text. Frederick L. Hovde, Arthur G. Hansen, and other more recent presidents recognized that engineers and scientists needed the humanities for a well-rounded education, yet one reason Purdue made few efforts to excel
WOODCUT OF PURDUE UNIVERSITY CAMPUS, C. 1877
Courtesy Purdue University Photo.
in those disciplines was that Indiana University already had a strong foothold in them. As in most states with two flagship universities there was rivalry, but in the Hoosier state it was kept in bounds. On many occasions the two educational giants cooperated in pleading their cases before the legislature.

The story Topping has chosen to tell he has told well. This is not a sentimental book designed to warm the hearts of old grads, but it tells an important and useful story about people and programs that have had an impact on the world. In an epilogue Purdue's current president, Steven C. Beering, pledges that the university will achieve ever greater distinction in the future. Thus it has always been with America's great educational institutions.
div.byline: GEORGE W. KNEPPER, distinguished professor of history, The University of Akron, Akron, Ohio , is the author of New Lamps for Old: One Hundred Years of Higher Education at The University of Akron (1970). Soon to be published is his new work, Ohio and Its People.

div.head: Vincennes: A Pictorial History. By Richard Day. (St. Louis, Mo.: G. Bradley Publishing, Inc., 1988. Pp. 216. Maps, illustrations, bibliography, index. $30.00.)
div.p: Vincennes: A Pictorial History has appeal for all members of an Indiana family—from youngster to oldster. Children can look at the pictures. School-agers can get easy intellectual gulps from history-filled captions. Parents can find interesting information about Vincennes from past to present. Grandparents will recall similar memories of their own existence.

The city of Vincennes has tremendous historical significance for the state of Indiana and its citizens. Author Richard Day notes that the name "Vincennes" can be traced back to France's "Forest of Vincennes" and that a migrated Bissot family named its estate on the St. Lawrence River the "Seignory of Vincennes." Son Jean Baptiste Bissot became the "Sieur de Vincennes," and in 1732 his son François Marie Bissot established a fort, later called Post Vincennes, along the Wabash River. Today Vincennes, Indiana, and France's city of Vincennes consider themselves "sister cities."

In 1778 a young, Virginia-born George Rogers Clark with fewer than two hundred soldiers captured Kaskaskia, Cahokia, and Vincennes. Then, in 1779, Clark recaptured Vincennes from the British lieutenant-governor, Henry Hamilton. In the twentieth century, through local and state efforts, a handsome George Rogers Clark Memorial was built at Vincennes with federal support. Considered by some the most impressive national monument west of Washington, D.C., and compared favorably with the Lincoln and Jefferson memorials in the nation's capital, this Indiana shrine is now operated by the United States National Park Service.

Day notes in his book many more places of historical interest in the Vincennes area. Three miles north of Vincennes is Fort Knox II, which has been reconstructed as a free, outdoor museum by the Indiana Historical Society. Grouseland, the Georgian home built by Indiana Territory's Governor William Henry Harrison in 1803-1804, has been restored and opened to the public by members of the Francis Vigo Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution. The two-story building that housed the early Indiana territorial legislature has also been preserved and is open to sightseers. Pictures of these important sites, plus many more snapshots of local places and activities, are collected in Day's volume.

Vincennes: A Pictorial History also provides a valuable summary of the economic history of the Vincennes community and a concise, twenty-year updating of the city's general history. After 1813 Vincennes was no longer the political focus of Indiana Territory, but it continued to be the commercial center for agricultural products raised throughout the Knox County area. After 1850 the town became a railroad center with both north-south and east-west lines. By 1900 Vincennes had become a center for manufacturing industries that used local coal and natural gas deposits. After 1950 the city saw a decline in manufacturing but an increase in job opportunities through the development of Vincennes University and the Good Samaritan Hospital. Thus, in the mid-twentieth century Vincennes was moving from an industrial to a service economy. In recent decades tourism has provided a third service-oriented boost to the city's economy.

Day, whose great-great-great-great-grandfather was among the local inhabitants who greeted Clark's troops in 1778, has had a lifelong interest in the history of Vincennes. His almost 9" x 12", 200-page volume contains a variety of illustrations that highlight many facets of community goings-on. Congratulations are in order for this meticulous, insightful contribution to local history.
div.byline: ROYAL ELLIS PURCELL III is a 1941 graduate of Indiana University with a major in political science and a minor in history. A native of Vincennes, Purcell now resides in Bloomington, Indiana.

div.head: An Evansville Album: Perspectives on a River City , 1812-1988. By Darrel E. Bigham. (Bloomington: Indiana University Press, in association with the Evansville Courier, 1988. Pp. ix, 163. illustrations, bibliography, index. $25.00.)
div.p:
This collection of images is, according to the author, "an attempt, through photographs, to chronicle the development of a city" (p. ix). To accomplish his goal Darrel E. Bigham has divided the book into four unequal sections. The first covers the years from 1812 to 1870 and is very short; the next two, from 1870 to 1915 and from 1915 to 1950, are approximately equal in size and are the
THE 1937 FLOOD AT EVANSVILLE, INDIANA
Reproduced from Darrel E. Bigham, An Evansville Album: Perspectives on a River City , 1819-1988 (Bloomington, 1988), 77. Courtesy University of Southern Indiana, Evansville. largest; the last section, from 1950 to 1988, is significantly shorter, although it is more than twice the length of the first. The division reflects both the significance of the respective eras and the availability of images. Bigham organizes each section to emphasize the developmental theme. In all save the first one he groups the images under four headings: riverfront/downtown, the changing cityscape, workers and the economy, and people. The pictures follow a short three-to-six page essay that provides background and context.

In the first section Bigham has only two headings—riverfront/downtown and people—and he uses as many prints as photographs to present his story. The remaining sections are comprised primarily of photographs from a variety of sources, including a few images made by Lewis Hine. The images are well reproduced, making the book attractive to read.

Bigham does not, however, achieve his goal. Part of the reason for this lack of success rests with the nature of historic photographs, which rarely show unguarded moments but are more often posed portraits that do not convey a sense of the texture or social
fabric of the past. Images of Evansville's physical landscape taken at different times are rarely exact duplicates, for example, and at times they portray human activities that distract from the theme of development. The images of workers and the economy and people often consist of group portraits in front of shops, businesses, factories, churches, and schools or at baseball parks. Such illustrations fail to discriminate in the way that Bigham intended and fail to sustain the theme that he imposes; nevertheless, An Evansville Album is an interesting collection of historic images.
div.byline: DWIGHT W. HOOVER is professor of history and director of the Center for Middletown Studies, Ball State University, Muncie, Indiana. He is author of Pictorial History of Indiana (1980) and Magic Middletown (1986), both of which use historic photographs. Hoover is currently working under an Indiana Humanties Council/Indiana Historical Society Heritage Grant to develop prints from the Otto Sellers glass plate negatives, which are housed at the Middletown Studies Center.

div.head: The Lincoln Highway: Main Street across America. By Drake Hokanson. (Iowa City: University of Iowa Press, 1988. Pp. xvi, 159. Illustrations, map, notes on sources, index. $32.50.)
div.p: A quick look through Drake Hokanson's The Lincoln Highway suggests that this is a "coffee table" book of pleasant black-and-white highway photographs. But a person taking just this superficial look will miss the wonderful mix of words and pictures that Hokanson uses to describe the development and demise of America's first "ocean to ocean" motorcar highway.

In 1912, long before the federal government built or financed the national highway system, a group of Indianapolis automobile manufacturers led by Carl Fisher met to make plans for a privately financed highway from New York to San Francisco. Fisher, whose Indianapolis racetrack was becoming a big success after he had paved the track with bricks in 1911, believed that the transcontinental highway would help attract attention to the automobile as a vehicle of long-distance travel.

Working from Fisher's dream and his early leadership, the Lincoln Highway Association began fund raising for mapping and construction. Although this private group succeeded in having a few short "seedling mile" segments of the route paved with concrete, it was not until after World War I with the help of federal financing that the highway was fully developed. Two-thirds of the 3,000-mile road followed a route that was later designated US. 30.

Hokanson provides details of the joys and frustrations of automobile travel during the years that the Lincoln Highway was being developed. His account of Emily Post's 1915 journey in a hand-built English touring car from New York to the Panama-Pacific International Exposition in San Francisco is a case in point. Very little of the route was paved in 1915, and Post's trip, which
VIEW FROM THE LINCOLN HIGHWAY NEAR LIGONIER, INDIANA
Reproduced from Drake Hokanson, The Lincoln Highway: Main Street across America (Iowa City, 1988), photograph section following p. 48. occurred during a rainy period, was made much longer as her party often had to wait for the road to dry to a passable condition.

Gradually the Lincoln Highway was improved and attracted more traffic; service businesses such as tourist courts, gasoline stations, and cafes opened for the motorists. As Hokanson traveled some twenty thousand miles on the road, he took special interest in these artifacts of the highway's heyday. He seemed, in fact, to take great delight in locating surviving Lincoln Highway markers from the three thousand that had been placed about every mile along the route in 1918 to direct the motorists across the country. Hokanson collected excellent historical photographs of life along the road, but his fine documentary photographs of the route today are the book's visual treat.

The modern interstate system has replaced the Lincoln Highway for most travelers, but many feel that these fast, limited-access routes homogenize the landscape and that the traveler today
may miss much of the country's flavor. Hokanson's words and pictures give strong evidence that driving across country may still be a pleasurable experience.
div.byline: WILL COUNTS is professor of journalism, Indiana University, Bloomington. He is currently working on a photographic essay of transcontinental highway US. 50.

div.head: A Photo Album of Ohio's Canal Era, 1825-1913. By Jack Gieck. Appendix by Frank W. Trevorrow and Barnett L. Golding. (Kent, Ohio : Kent State University Press, 1988. Pp. xix, 310. Illustrations, notes, maps, figures, tables, appendix, index. $35.00.)
div.p: In a visually conscious age illustrated histories with original and thought-provoking commentary can be an effective way to link people with the past. Jack Gieck uses the medium of an illustrated history to commemorate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Canal Society of Ohio . The pictures are annotated and accompanied by a narrative explaining the various stages of the construction and operation of canals in Ohio . The presentation is at its best when the pictures are allowed to tell their own story and when the commentary is limited to annotation.

From the illustrations of the primitive tools, massive superstructures, and workers at the sites one gets some idea of the back-breaking manual labor and technical skill required to build a canal. From the illustrations of canals bounded by wharfs and warehouse—which touch an environmentalist nerve—one catches a glimpse of the economic usefulness of these waterways during their heyday. And from the illustrations of sturdy women and phlegmatic-looking old men posing on the decks of their canal-borne homes, one almost experiences nostalgia for a bygone era when life looked so restful and uncomplicated.

A photograph album is appropriate for the author's purpose and should interest anyone enthused by Ohio and Indiana canal history. Indeed, anyone interested in photography should also find some particular delights in this work.
div.byline: CATHERINE TOBIN, a temporary assistant professor at Central Michigan University, Mt. Pleasant, is currently reworking her dissertation on Irish canal workers for publication.

div.head: The Politics of Community: Migration and Politics in Antebellum Ohio . By Kenneth J. Winkle. (Cambridge, England: Cambridge University Press, 1988. Pp. xiii, 239. Maps, figures, tables, notes, bibliography, index. $29.95.)
div.p:
Scholarly interest in the antebellum Midwest has been flourishing in recent years, and Kenneth J. Winkle's study of migration and political development in Ohio is a welcome addition to a growing
collection of monographs in this area. Although based on a case study from Ohio , this provocative book is much more than a parochial view of one state or region. Migration was probably the single most important factor influencing the nation's social and political development during the nineteenth century, and Ohio , which lay astride a great east-west human conduit, remained at the center of this great movement.

The discovery that Americans moved a great deal during the decades prior to the Civil War is not new, but Winkle's ingenious use of sources allows him to refine this general picture considerably. Using Ohio quadrennial census reports and county poll books, Winkle argues that persistence in Ohio between 1850 and 1860 was much lower than previously assumed. Winkle's evidence is based primarily on data from a single predominantly rural county, but if this pattern was in fact typical, then it makes even more compelling the question of how communities that were experiencing such great mobility created political stability and order.

Prior to 1841 Ohio townships acted as "consensual communities" that controlled access to the franchise. State registration laws, for example, gave townships effective power to prevent recent immigrants from voting and otherwise to determine participation in elections. Political stability resulted from excluding transients and newcomers until they had proven their stake in the community. When local autonomy was undermined by an 1841 election law that established nine objective criteria for registering voters, highly mobile individuals could decide for themselves, within the limits of the law, their legal political residence. As the former basis of stability and continuity was destroyed, political parties were forced to compete with each other more aggressively for the allegiance of new voters. Political alignments, nevertheless, remained surprisingly stable from election to election.

Winkle's explanations of how political continuity was maintained under the new law are less satisfying than other parts of his study and are not remarkably new. Like many others he argues that those least likely to move—wealthy professionals and merchants—formed an elite core of elected leaders who provided a basis for continuity in each community. These local leaders further enhanced stability by attracting and organizing into political parties voters from among the more mobile portion of the population. As a result, parties became increasingly inclusive in order to absorb migrant voters.

Although Winkle does not state it so boldly, the logical conclusion to his study is that large-scale migration hastened the liberalization of American politics. No longer could consensual communities maintain order, unity, and continuity by controlling the privileges of political participation. Mobility forced communities
to recognize the political rights of rootless individuals who had only tenuous connections with a particular place.
div.byline: EMIL POCOCK, Eastern Connecticut State University, Willimantic, is completing a study of the decline of republican political and community values in early Ohio .

div.head: A House Divided: Sectionalism and Civil War, 1848-1865. By Richard H. Sewell. (Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press, 1988. Pp. xii, 223. Maps, bibliographical essay, index. Cloth-bound, $29.50; paperbound, $9.95.)
div.p: Richard H. Sewell, biographer of the Free Soiler-Radical Republican John P. Hale and author of Ballots for Freedom: Antislavery Politics in the United States , 1837-1860 (1976), moves in this book from political historical specialist to synthesist. He has made the transition with spectacular success. In refocusing "attention on slavery as the taproot of sectional discord and civil war," Sewell offers a "modest challenge to those historians who see slavery as a largely artificial or symbolic issue and who emphasize instead the role of such ‘ethnocultural’ concerns as temperance and nativism in shaping public events …" (p. xi). Happily, the challenge is very modest, never disputatious, and indeed hardly discernible. He avoids the error that is too prevalent among Civil War historians of reading back into the minds of past generations the knowledge and values of the late twentieth century. He brings to his work the sagacity of the late David Potter and the provocative insights of Bertram Wyatt-Brown.

In contrast with some historical interpretations, Sewell's argument is that a kind of southern nationalism did exist prior to the Civil War, a nationalism that derived "more from shared fears and resentments than from a common, unique cultural identity. … rightly or wrongly, many southerners had come to believe that theirs was a distinctive way of life" (p. 79). Also relevant was a mid-nineteenth century concept of "honor" that is foreign to the late twentieth century American mind. It follows that southern secession, no matter how ill-advised scholars now know it to have been, was the expected rather than the unexpected southern reaction to Abraham Lincoln's election, for the Republican victory in 1860, following a decade of sectional controversy, "represented an assault on the honor and well-being of the South" (p. 78). Thus, while the words "tragic" and "tragedy" hardly ever appear in his book, Sewell is sensitive to the pervasive tragic theme in the history of the Civil War era.

A chapter entitled "The War at Home" is a masterly account of the impact of war on civilians of all classes and stations, North and South. In a chapter called "The Destruction of Slavery" Sewell recounts how emancipation began early in the war, escalated gradually
to 1865, and culminated in the establishment of the Freed-men's Bureau and the ratification of the Thirteenth Amendment. Paralleling wartime emancipation was wartime reconstruction, which began at least as early as 1863 and probably earlier.

The book is free of serious flaws. Although Lincoln and Stephen A. Douglas are given prominent roles in the political history of the 1850s, there is no narrative or analysis, per se, of the Lincoln-Douglas debates of 1858. Sewell's account of the former slave as soldier, pupil, and wage earner may be somewhat roseate, but the general excellence of the book overshadows these problems. Sewell's prose is always lucid and sometimes sparkling. His knowledge of the primary and secondary sources enables him to illustrate the narrative with apt quotations and lends to the book an aura of authenticity. This sophisticated, but never recondite, book will be widely read and enjoyed. If there is a better book of its genre on the period 1845-1865, this reviewer does not know what it is.
div.byline: PATRICK W. RIDDLEBERGER, history professor emeritus, Southern Illinois University at Edwardsville, is author of George Washington Julian, Radical Republican (1966) and 1866: The Critical Year Revisited (1979). He is currently working on a general history of Reconstruction.

div.head: Melting Pot Soldiers: The Union's Ethnic Regiments. By William L. Burton. (Ames: Iowa State University Press, 1988. Pp. x, 282. Illustrations, notes, selected bibliography, index. $26.95.)
div.p: William L. Burton's Melting Pot Soldiers is a far more ambitious book than its title suggests. In addition to dealing with the formation, problems, and performance of immigrant units from Illinois, Indiana, Massachusetts, Missouri, New York, Ohio , Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin, the author places their story in a wider context of comparative ethnic history. Despite his choice of subject, however, Burton surprisingly downplays ethnic conflict and even argues that nativism was not a particularly powerful force in American politics by the eve of the Civil War. Indeed he is so successful in showing how ethnic regiments were similar in both attitudes and behavior to other Civil War regiments that some readers may finish the book wondering if there is any justification for studying ethnic regiments in their own right. If these generalizations were not controversial enough, Burton also sharply criticizes the filiopietism of older works in ethnic history and scathingly indicts those historians who have celebrated the "contributions" of various ethnic groups without subjecting them to the same kind of critical analysis that is routinely applied to the native born.

In fact, some of the best chapters in the book deal with the often shady politics of recruiting ethnic regiments. Burton neatly describes the labyrinthine maneuvering involved in the selection
of colonels and other junior officers. His argument that this process simply marked a continuation of prewar ethnic politics is an especially useful one. At the same time Burton gives careful attention to the various experiences of ethnic regiments both in camp and in battle but avoids turning the leaders of these units into either heroes or villains. The complex interplay of patriotism and opportunism in the ethnic regiments in many ways reflected the larger, unresolved ambiguities of a polyglot culture. With a keen eye for social context Burton observes that there was often more tension between competing ethnic groups than between the foreign born and natives; therefore, any attempt to describe a simple power struggle between a bigoted Anglo-Saxon establishment and their Irish and German neighbors inevitably ignores much contrary evidence.

Despite the author's overall success and useful interpretations, the book does have shortcomings. At the beginning there is much confusing detail with seemingly little purpose, and organizational problems crop up throughout the work. In the long chapters on the German and Irish regiments the author plods along from state to state and regiment to regiment, an approach that often obscures his analytical purpose. More generally, he should have taken much more care on the transitions between chapters, sections, and paragraphs. On balance, however, the strong points outweigh the weak ones; and even though many historians will accuse Burton of painting a far too rosy picture of the nineteenth century American social order, they will have to reckon with this sometimes original, often persuasive, and always provocative treatment of a neglected topic.
div.byline: GEORGE C. RABLE, associate professor of history and director of American Studies, Anderson University, Anderson, Indiana, is the author of But There Was No Peace: The Role of Violence in the Politics of Reconstruction (1984) and Civil Wars: Women and the Crisis of Southern Nationalism (1989).

div.head: Tippecanoe and Trinkets Too: The Material Culture of American Presidential Campaigns, 1828-1984. By Roger A. Fischer. (Urbana: University of Illinois Press, 1988. Pp. x, 322. Illustrations, notes, sources, index. $34.95.)
div.p:
Before sound bites there were political campaign buttons; before thirty-second spots, lusterware teapots. Campaign objects designed to influence voters appeared during the 1828 contest between incumbent John Quincy Adams and General Andrew Jackson. Then, in 1840, Whig managers used imagery to transform the aristocratic General William Henry Harrison into an icon of rusticity. Images of log cabins and cider barrels decorated pitchers, plates, and bandannas. In one 1840 Whig depiction "Wm. H. Harrison, The Ohio Farmer" steps from a log cabin set amid a productive
landscape and greets a one-legged veteran while a third man taps a hospitable barrel. It was masterfully misrepresentative "hum-buggery"—in Jackson's word—but it transformed American politics. Henceforth, technology would produce easy-to-grasp icons and images, artifacts rather than ideas.

Roger A. Fischer's Tippecanoe and Trinkets Too describes this "Material Culture of American Presidential Campaigns, 1828-1984." In his preface the author accuses historians of "tunnel vision." They should use "presidential campaign material culture … to reflect in their research … the true multifaceted complexity" of political campaigns in the way that archaeologists have "reconstructed whole civilizations." Tippecanoe and Trinkets Too seeks to bridge "two disparate groups: the curators, antiquarians, and collectors … and the academic historians …" (p. vii). The book outlines some electoral history for the former and describes trinkets for the latter.

The book has some difficulties. The outline unfortunately jumps from one election to the next without analyses of issues, events, and trends that would help to explain these quadrennial contests. Descriptions of trinkets summarize trinket catalogs and compound slogans into quotation-filled paragraphs. Further, one might doubt if material culture can enlighten the "true multifaceted complexity" of American politics. The author concludes that "it cannot be stated with any degree of certainty that the outcome of any American presidential election has been determined by its material culture" (p. 303). Objects defined Harrison in 1840 and Abraham Lincoln in 1860 and may have maintained electoral enthusiasm in pivotal northern states during the latter nineteenth century, but the book does not then define how political historians can use this material. Political objects in this book merely restate adequately known campaign slogans. An artifact's "message" depends upon who produced it—national campaign leaders,
state and local campaigns, commercial vendors. Asserting without explanation that "the 1920-48 period was a rather lean one for political textiles" (p. 191) leads historians nowhere.

Still, persons fond of elections will enjoy the book. For collectors the most interesting year may well be 1908, when postcards, celluloid buttons (patented in 1896), pins, trays, umbrellas, and endless bric-a-brac were artfully arrayed with names, pictures, and slogans. For historians the most bizarre artifact to contemplate may be an 1896 William McKinley campaign soap doll placed in a coffin-like box. For material specialists the most effective campaign object to analyze is, of course, "I Like Ike."
div.byline: HOWARD F. MCMAINS, editor of the Organization of American Historians Newsletter, has written articles on modern American history and collects political campaign buttons.

div.head: The Party of Fear: From Nativist Movements to the New Right in American History. By David H. Bennett. (Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press, 1988. Pp. x, 509. Frontispiece, notes, index. $29.95.)
div.p: This ambitious survey of nativist and counter-subversive movements from colonial times to the present examines a wide array of groups ranging from the Know-Nothings to the Moral Majority. Building on foundations laid by such pioneers in the field as Ray Allen Billington and John Higham, David H. Bennett echoes recent scholarship in maintaining that the "antialiens" should not be dismissed as irrational bigots. They had genuine concerns, the author contends, and deserve "dispassionate attention" since they "have reflected tensions endemic … in the very structure of American life" (p. 6). They included frauds and opportunists, their actions were often reprehensible, and their movements, seeking scapegoats, generally obscured the impersonal social and economic forces largely responsible for their dilemma. Still, most sincerely viewed America as a threatened Eden needing protection from intruders and alien ideas.

The Party of Fear rests on impressive research, and its main thesis is persuasive. The identification of nativism with the political right, however, diminishes the complexity of a cause that found some support, as Bennett himself acknowledges, from other sources, including abolitionists, labor leaders, and progressive reformers. Similarly, the author might have noted that fear of a polluted Eden was not limited to antialiens.

A detailed examination of the historical context in which the antialien movement developed adds to the book's strength. Particularly fascinating is the account of the upheaval created by the influx of Germans and Irish before the Civil War. At times Bennett rehashes familiar details, as in his discussion of Joseph McCarthy.
Plodding state by state analyses of larger nativist movements impede the book's general flow, but the several pages Bennett devotes to the Know-Nothings and Klan in Indiana furnish serviceable introductions, if no fresh insights, to the subjects. Bennett's endnotes will direct the uninitiated to basic primary and secondary sources.

After restrictions were placed on immigration during the 1920s, Bennett writes, alien ideas, particularly communism, came increasingly to displace immigrants as the prime obsession of the antialiens. He depicts Father Coughlin's movement as "an inverted nativism" that provided Catholics and ethnic followers "a way of striking back at ancient oppressors" (p. 509). McCarthy, another Catholic, singled out the establishment, not aliens, as his target. Bennett maintains that even anti-communism has now lost most of its appeal and that nativism itself has all but disappeared in contemporary society despite the continuation of miniscule, if violent, groups like the Order.

True, today there is no movement on the scale of the Klan of the 1920s. Yet Bennett's claim that the current agitation over illegal aliens and bilingualism is largely divorced from nativist sentiment is debatable, and he gives little attention to the harsh reception received by recent arrivals from Asia and Latin America. Nonetheless, The Party of Fear provides a valuable framework for understanding a phenomenon central to the American experience, even if it may be premature to administer last rites.
div.byline: ALLEN SAFIANOW, professor of history, Indiana University at Kokomo, has conducted research on Indiana Ku Klux Klan activities in the 1920s. His article "Konklave in Kokomo Revisited was published in the May, 1988, issue of The Historian.

div.head: Farm Families & Change in Twentieth-Century America. By Mark Friedberger. (Lexington: University Press of Kentucky, 1988. Pp. x, 282. Tables, note on sources and methods, notes, index. $28.00.)
div.p: Mark Friedberger's Farm Families & Change in Twentieth-Century America is mainly about how farm families have coped with the rapid and dramatic changes in the agricultural business during this century. Concentrating on California's Central Valley and northeastern Iowa, Friedberger argues that American agriculture has remained basically family oriented. He chooses examples from each area to illustrate the strategies that families pursued to acquire land, expand, innovate, and survive from generation to generation. Friedberger's book will reassure those who see the cherished family farm melting away. His wishful conclusion that the recent agricultural crisis may actually strengthen that entity will hearten those who foresee Beatrice and Tenneco farming the whole country.

Friedberger's focus on the familial nature of American agriculture is apt, but his evidence is not always compelling. Readers will wonder, for example, about the typicality of his case studies and about distinctions that sometimes fail to show differences. Readers might also question the appropriateness of labeling massive, highly capitalized Central Valley operations "family farms" just because family corporations own them.

Friedberger's most serious shortcoming, however, lies not in his primary thrust but in his unwillingness to press it clearly or rigorously enough. In the process of supporting his thesis he strays into discussions of crop production methods, the agricultural ladder, the legal ramifications of and the variant psychological reactions to the farm crisis, and other topics. All of these subjects are tangentially related to his major purpose, but his discursions give the book an unarticulated quality. The book is also flawed by dubious reasoning and questionable conclusions. Friedberger contends, for example, that Portuguese farmers in the Central Valley "never" had "confrontations over farm labor" because they relied on family labor (p. 58), and he argues that Auburn, Iowa, suffered no German-baiting during World War I because surrounding communities admired the local priest. At other times Friedberger displays a firm grasp of the obvious, as when he assures readers that landlords "sought to rent their land to competent tenants" (p. 52).

All of these problems are unfortunate because they detract from a tale worth telling. Friedberger knows a great deal about farm families, and he does a nice job of identifying those traits—-e.g., fiscal conservatism, diversification of production, family solidarity, prudent innovation, and hard work—that have helped them survive. It is unfortunate that the reader has to pick through so much chaff to find the kernels.
div.byline: DAVID B. DANBOM, professor of history, North Dakota State University, Fargo, is presently completing a history of the North Dakota Agricultural Experiment Station.

div.head: Toward a Well-Fed World. By Don Paarlberg. (Ames: Iowa State University Press, 1988. Pp. xviii, 270. References, tables, index. $24.95.)
div.p: Hunger is the most important motivational force among humans, and it is the oldest enemy of mankind. Crop failure, war, and rapid population growth are fundamental causes of hunger, while civil disorder, disease, and death are its consequences. Increased agricultural production, domestic and foreign food aid, expanded trade, migration, and family planning help alleviate or prevent hunger and the threat of famine.

Don Paarlberg, former distinguished professor at Purdue University and longtime public servant, has surveyed the work of more
than two dozen men and women who have made major contributions to agricultural science, food aid, and family planning at home and abroad during the past two centuries. He also notes the significance of antibiotics and chemical and biological pest controls and the influence of the land-grant college, experiment station, and cooperative extension systems. Only in the broadest sense, however, can one directly relate this study to the fight against hunger. While Norman Borlaug certainly merits recognition for helping improve the food supply in Third World countries, John McCormick primarily sought personal economic gain and technological achievement, the latter of which incidentally helped increase agricultural production. Paarlberg also generalizes too much when he contends that hunger has been driven from the United States ; nevertheless, he correctly maintains that the world is better fed than ever before and that a Malthusian disaster does not loom on the horizon. Still, he recognizes that much work needs to be done before hunger will be eliminated on a worldwide basis.

Paarlberg has written a collection of vignettes that will provide an introduction for students and general readers who want to learn more about important individual contributions to agricultural science, food aid, and family planning. Although he is perceptive, Paarlberg is not always a critical judge of the past; nevertheless, he has provided a clearly written survey of the major individual, institutional, and national efforts that have directly or indirectly helped combat the age-old problems of hunger and famine.
div.byline: R. DOUGLAS HURT, director of the Center for Agricultural History and Rural Life, Ames, Iowa, has published widely in the field of American agricultural history. His most recent book is Indian Agriculture in America: Prehistory to the Present (1987).

div.head: From Front Porch to Back Seat: Courtship in Twentieth-Century America. By Beth L. Bailey. (Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press, 1988. Pp. x, 181. Illustrations, notes, index. $18.95.)
div.p:
Given its rather provocative title, a casual reader might well expect From Front Porch to Back Seat to be a somewhat racy volume—something along the lines of National Enquirer with a little Hugh Hefner thrown in. But historian Beth L. Bailey has written a serious book on a topic of growing fascination to social historians. In a very brief space—fewer than 150 pages of text—Bailey seeks to analyze the fundamental courtship rituals and conventions of young, white, middle-class Americans from 1920 to 1965. Using popular magazines, advice and etiquette books, college newspapers, and texts and journal articles from marriage courses in schools, the author contends that in this period courtship moved from "the controlling contexts of home and community" and "became more and
more a private act conducted in the public world" (p. 3). At the same time young men and women increasingly rejected the concept of "playing the field" for a rather intense need to "go steady."

A brief review cannot do full justice to this complex and densely packed work. Bailey is especially effective and provocative in building her central model: that dating conventions were deeply tied to an essentially commercial relationship. One of the author's favorite words is "commodification," as she argues that the whole concept of dating as it evolved in the twentieth century in essence allowed men to "purchase" women by asking for dates and paying for the experience. Indeed, the quite non-economic word "love" seldom appears in this study. As Bailey puts it, "love was not so much the province of convention. … I will leave love to lovers in private and examine the public conventions of desire" (p. 12).

This fine study expands beautifully on the work of Joseph F. Kett and Paula S. Fass, but it is not without flaws. Bailey tends to overwork the new jargon; words like "privilege" used as a verb, "discourse," and "subtextually" dot the text. The topical organization is sometimes confusing. And Bailey could profitably write a second book on the subject—one in which she broadens her scope beyond the young, the white, and the middle class. Next time she might even try to show what, if anything, love has to do with it.
div.byline: ANTHONY O. EDMONDS, professor and chairman of the Department of History, Ball State University, Muncie, Indiana, has written a biography of Joe Louis and is currently working on a study of the impact of the Vietnam War on Muncie, Indiana.

div.head: Cincinnati and the Big Red Machine. By Robert Harris Walker. (Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 1988. Pp. xvi, 158. Illustrations, note on sources, index. Clothbound, $19.95; paperbound, $8.95.)
div.p: For Cincinnati Reds fans a new book about their favorite team is always welcome, and Robert Harris Walker has written a different kind of Reds volume. Other books concentrate on the history of the Reds as a baseball team; Walker places the history of the team within the context of the city of Cincinnati and its geographical region, which includes the southwestern part of Indiana.

Walker's book grew out of a series of interviews with players, managers, owners, and Queen City residents. The first chapter opens with the All-star game in 1970 when Pete Rose slid into home plate to score the controversial winning run. A history of professional baseball in Cincinnati follows, and a brief history of the city highlighting its German heritage gives an insight into the character of the town and the region. Walker credits the building of Riverfront Stadium for revitalizing Cincinnati's downtown area. Further testimony to the importance of baseball to the Queen City was the emphasis given the 1988 All-star game in Cincinnati's

Courtesy Archives and Rare Books Department, University of Cincinnati Libraries, Cincinnati, Ohio . bicentennial celebration. In addition, the Cincinnati Historical Society devoted an entire issue of its Queen City Heritage to baseball.

Walker grew up in Cincinnati, and his early life revolved around the success or lack of success of the Reds. He attended his first game at age eight and still treasures the scorecard from that memorable game. "The Big Red Machine" noted in the title of his book refers, of course, to the Reds teams of the 1970s. A large portion of the text and many pictures are devoted to analysis of those teams. Interviews with players, coaches, and other persons who were closely involved with the glory years of the Cincinnati Reds will be dear to the heart of any fan.

For the baseball fan Cincinnati and the Big Red Machine gives a bit too much civic history; for the historian the role of baseball in the town's history is overemphasized; but for a person who is fan of both baseball and history, this book is recommended for an evening's entertainment.
div.byline: RUTH DORREL, a Cincinnati Reds fan since 1958, is editor of The Hoosier Genealogist, which is published by the Indiana Historical Society, Indianapolis.

div.head: Kinsmen Through Time: An Annotated Bibliography of Potawatomi History. By R. David Edmunds. (Metuchen, N.J.: Scarecrow Press, Inc., 1987. Pp. xviii, 217. Index. $25.00.)
Civil War Eyewitnesses: An Annotated Bibliography of Books and Articles, 1955-1986. By Garold L. Cole. (Columbia: University of South Carolina Press, 1988. Pp. viii, 351. Index. $29.95.)
div.p: Two recent bibliographies make major contributions to research in Potawatomi history and Civil War history.

Kinsmen Through Time was compiled by R. David Edmunds, generally considered the leading authority on the Potawatomis and now a member of the history department at Indiana University, Bloomington. The bibliography has 1,092 entries and lists books, pamphlets, articles, and unpublished theses and dissertations. Following an initial section of "General Studies," the work is divided into five chronological periods ranging from the early contact period to the twentieth century. The preface provides a helpful overview of Potawatomi history. The index does not include authors or titles, but it covers subjects very thoroughly and helps in locating books that do not fall easily into the chronological framework. Edmunds guides the reader to specific volumes in large sets, such as the Collections of the Illinois State Historical Library and the Collections of the Michigan Pioneer and Historical Society, which contain substantial information on the Potawatomis. In addition, for those wishing to go beyond this bibliography Edmunds refers in his preface to unpublished source materials. Acknowledging that any bibliography is out-of-date as soon as it is published, Edmunds nevertheless states, "I am confident that this bibliography contains well over 95 percent of all significant Potawatomi materials (excluding congressional documents) published in the United States or Canada prior to 1985" (p. xvii). There seems to be no reason to doubt his statement.

Garold L. Cole's bibliography of books and articles covers publications that appeared from 1955 through 1986, the period during which the Civil War centennial inspired renewed interest in firsthand accounts of that conflict. As Cole states in his introduction, this volume is intended to complement works covering earlier publications, including Charles E. Dornbusch's Military Bibliography of the Civil War (1961-1972) and James I. Robertson and Bell I. Wiley's Civil War Books (1965-1967). Cole's book surpasses these, however, in both its coverage and detailed annotations. The 1,395 entries are divided into three categories: "The North," "The South," and "Anthologies and Studies." The first two sections are subdivided into accounts by members of the military, by civilians, and by travelers. The last is divided into general studies, studies of the
North, and studies of the South. The detailed index includes authors and editors of narratives, titles, state troops, names of battles, places, and subjects.

These volumes are annotated bibliographies in the best and fullest sense of the term. They provide detailed notes in each entry, and Cole includes many quotations from the original accounts as part of the annotation. Each will give the researcher an invaluable overview of the literature available in its area, and each is indispensable to any student of the subject covered.
div.byline: LEIGH DARBEE is curator of printed collections and head of reference, Indiana Historical Society Library, Indianapolis. She is currently working on a bibliography of the society's books and maps printed through the year 1840.

div.head: Handbook for Research in American History: A Guide to Bibliographies and Other Reference Works. By Francis Paul Prucha. (Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 1987. Pp. xiii, 289. Index. Clothbound, $21.95; paperbound, $9.95.)
div.p: Any reference book is outdated before it appears; publishers annually produce a vast array of guides and bibliographies, which, because of the inevitable time lag between the completion of a manuscript and the appearance of a published volume, cannot contain the very latest sources. Now about two years out of date, Francis Paul Prucha's helpful list of reference sources is no exception; that fact, however, should not seriously detract from its general usefulness as an introductory guide.

Handbook for Research in American History is intended to introduce beginning, established, and "non" historians "to the helps that await them in the reference sections of the library" (p. 1). Although it is not heavily annotated, it can serve to orient a beginning researcher, who may then choose to consult more complete compilations, most notably the tenth edition of Eugene P. Sheehy's Guide to Reference Books (1986), to which the present volume owes a great debt. The Handbook will be less useful to seasoned researchers.

Divided into two sections, part one of Prucha's Handbook is arranged into seventeen chapters by type of reference source (general bibliographies, guides to periodical literature, manuscript guides, lists of dissertations and theses, etc.). Part two is a subject arrangement covering fifteen areas from American Indians, Blacks, and Military History, to Religion, Regional Material, and Travel Accounts. Because Prucha chose to omit most older publications in this second section, however, researchers may find it necessary to seek supplementary information in other subject bibliographies.

Although the Handbook will be helpful in making concise references to complete citations that appear elsewhere, users of the volume may require some patience in coping with the alphanumeric
designations used for listed titles, which difficulty is especially apparent in the index, where page references, by and large, are omitted.

The first part of the Handbook is probably more beneficial than the second. Although the reference work cannot claim to cover any new ground, the intelligence with which Prucha arranges and explains his selection of materials will assist many beginning historians. Part two is less successful, but only because of its subject limitations. The selection of topics "that are likely to be of interest to considerable numbers of researchers in United States history" (p. 141) seems quite arbitrary, a fact that Prucha acknowledges. Thus, more traditional subject fields, such as architecture, literature, and sociology, are omitted in lieu of those in more current favor, and this section will consequently be useful only if one happens to be researching one of the subjects considered. Because the Handbook is selective, not exhaustive, many sources are naturally omitted from both sections; but sound reasons could no doubt be given for such exclusions, and the author never claims comprehensiveness.

The impetus behind Handbook for Research in American History is well founded, and researchers in Indiana history will find numerous citations to pertinent reference sources in virtually every section. The book should not replace library orientation courses, which are offered at many colleges and universities, and cannot replace more massive compilations, such as Sheehy's Guide, already noted. As a book to convey information about selected reference sources in American history, however, it will serve its audience well and perhaps will whet the appetite of the newly initiated to delve even more deeply into the labyrinthian world of reference and bibliography.
div.byline: BRUCE L. JOHNSON is director of the Indiana Historical Society Library, Indianapolis. Formerly a lecturer in the School of Library and Information Studies, University of California at Berkeley, and library director of the California Historical Society, Johnson has published extensively in the field of historical bibliography. He is beginning work on a study of commercial printing, publishing, and ancillary activities in nineteenth century Indiana.

div.head: Stone Age Spear and Arrow Points of the Midcontinental and Eastern United States : A Modern Survey and Reference. By Noel D. Justice. (Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 1987. Pp. xiv, 288. Illustrations, figures, maps, appendix, references, index. $37.50.)
div.p:
Professional and avocational archaeologists alike will welcome Noel D. Justice's synthesis of types of projectile points for the mid-continental and eastern United States . No one has heretofore attempted a study covering such a large area, although there are
several works on subregions of the East. Justice's well-researched volume organizes typological data from the best archaeological contexts from the eastern United States according to increasingly accepted "type clusters." This is a very rational organizational method given the amount of variability that is evident from statistical analyses of haft morphology at several stratified sites in the region covered by the study. Much of Justice's characterization of the early time periods is sound, and his inclusion of a number of illustrated points from excavations directed by Jefferson Chapman in Tellico Reservoir is significant. These stratigraphic deposits, along with those at Koster, St. Albans, Doerschuk, Pigeon's Roost, and other lesser known sites, have altered expectations about typological homogeneity in the Archaic because the earliest deeply stratified contexts were rockshelters (Russell Cave, Stanfield-Worley, Modoc, and Graham Cave), shallow upland contexts (Hardaway, Dalton, and Quad), or shell middens (Eva and Indian Knoll). In these contexts individual occupations are barely separated by depositional events; thus, it is not surprising to find more morphological variability (as measured by the number of point types per stratum) than in contexts such as Rose Island, Icehouse Bottom, Doerschuk, St. Albans, and Koster.

The book's eight color plates illustrate the various levels of skill and the range of flint and chert utilized by the native inhabitants of the Midcontinent and Indiana in particular. Justice presents descriptions of manufacture technique, resultant morphology, age, and cultural affiliation and very useful distributional maps for a total of 121 types grouped into 50 type clusters. The quality of information so presented is consistent throughout and will be particularly helpful to contract archaeologists who find themselves working in unfamiliar parts of the country.

This self-proclaimed manual is a very satisfactory compilation of extant knowledge of projectile point classifications. The book's only weakness in this regard is the differential number of point types utilized for the Archaic and Woodland traditions as compared to the Mississippian. This differential is at once evidence of the variable effort placed upon this particular functional class of stone tools by hunter-gatherer specialists and perhaps of the variability that did, in fact, exist in dart versus arrow weapon systems. At any rate, anyone wishing to pursue these questions will be well armed with this manual.
div.byline: LARRY R. KIMBALL, Department of Anthropology, Northwestern University, Evans-ton, Illinois, has conducted field and laboratory research in the southeastern United States and southwestern France. He has published on lithic technology, archaeological survey, spatial analysis, quantitative methods, microwear analysis, and the Paleolithic, and he has recently completed a functional study of Upper Paleolithic tools from the Periogord region of France.
